Although  the  Government  recognizes  the  importance  of  the

barriers  to  development,  reflected  by  limited  growth,  informality,

Successful implementation of the Program entails three risks. The 
first  relates  to  a  lack  of  capacity  within  the  Government  to 
implement  some  of  the  complex  reforms.  In  previous  programs, 
delays  were  caused  predominantly  by  the  lack  of  technical 
expertise.  To  address  this  risk,  an  advisory  TA  has  been 
designed,  in  coordination  with  other  development  agencies  to 
support Program implementation, and engage in capacity-building 
measures for relevant Government officials. 
 
A  second  risk  relates  to  lack  of  coordination  among  various 
Government  agencies.  The  Program  requires  close  coordination 
among the relevant authorities—both horizontally among different 
ministries  and  agencies  concerned,  and  vertically  with  the 
provincial  and  district  authorities.  Consultation  and  coordination 
will  also  be  required  with  other  stakeholders  active  in  SME 
development.  The  Program  design  addresses 
this  risk  by 
emphasizing  the  use  of  interagency  coordination  mechanisms, 
particularly  by  establishing  an  inter-ministerial  coordination  body 
(National SME Subcommittee) with private sector participation. 
 
A  third  risk  relates  to  good  governance  of  the  central  and  local 
government authorities. Local governance is particularly important 
as that is where the Program will have the most direct impact on 
SMEs.  The  Government  is  addressing  these  risks,  which  are 
common  to  several  programs,  through  implementation  of  the 
comprehensive  Public  Financial  Management  Program, 
(supported by several development agencies, including ADB).  
 
The  Government  asked  ADB  to  provide  TA  to  build  capacity  for 
SME  development  for  $0.85  million.  The  TA  will  be  financed  by 
ADB  ($500,000),  and  the  Government  of  Denmark  ($350,000). 
The  TA  will  focus  on  (i)  technical,  legal,  and  policy-related

i. 

Business Registration System  

Although  the  decision  to  register12 should  be  at  the  discretion  of  each  enterprise,  the 
20. 
difficulties  of  registering  have  important  implications.  Under  the  current  legal  framework, 
unregistered  enterprises  (i)  cannot  engage  in  foreign  trade;  (ii)  cannot  obtain  various  tax 
benefits;  (iii)  cannot  secure  their  assets  in  public  registries,  which  are  being  developed  in 
Cambodia;  (iv)  cannot  engage  in  legally  protected  commercial  contracts  in  the  name  of  the 
enterprise as a legal entity; (v) do not qualify for government procurement; (vi) have no legally 
protected rights of shareholders; or (vii) cannot seek protection through corporate bankruptcy. In 
addition,  although  unregistered  enterprises  are  not  explicitly  excluded,  they  are  also  likely  to 
have  difficulties  with  (i)  engaging  in  subcontracting  with  foreign  enterprises;  (ii)  validating 
commercial  contracts  through  the  corporate  entity;  and  (iii)  obtaining  loans  from  banks,  which 
usually  prefer  to  lend  to  registered  companies.  Finally,  the  barriers  against  registration  also 
discourage  enterprises  from  incorporating  themselves  as  limited  liability  companies—meaning 
that  the  owners  assume  all  the  risks  associated  with  the  enterprise  activities,  as  no  legal 
separation exists between the owner(s) and the enterprise.  
 
The  major  impediments  to  business  registration  are  as  follows.  First,  the  costs  of 
21. 
registration  are  currently  about  $1,200  to  $1,500  (four  to  five  times  per  capita  GDP)  and  the 
highest  in  the  Mekong  region.13 Second,  the  approximately  17  processes  and  documentation 
requirements  involve  various  local  and  central  government  agencies.14 Third,  enterprises  must 
register  at  the  Ministry  of  Commerce  (MOC)  building  in  Phnom  Penh.  Entrepreneurs  must 
therefore  travel  to  Phnom  Penh,  often  several  times,  to  register  their  enterprises.  Fourth,  the 
minimum  capital  requirement  for  business  registration  is  set  at  $5,000  (about  16  times 
Cambodia's  per  capita  GDP)  and  is  higher  than  in  neighboring  countries.  The  requirement  is 
based  solely  on  cash  deposits  at  a  commercial  bank  and,  accordingly,  takes  no  account  of 
assets  that  a  company  may  have.  Finally,  for  the  Government,  lack  of  information  technology 
precludes an efficient registration system and effective storage of data.  
 

ii. 

Business Operating and Regulatory Licensing System 

22. 
Although  most  countries  commonly  have  several  agencies  that  issue  specific  business 
licenses, Cambodia currently lacks a systematic approach to limit the burden on enterprises. On 
average, Cambodian firms are subject to more than 16 license inspections per year. In addition, 
business-operating licenses need to be renewed on a continual basis. The formal and informal 
payments  for  obtaining  both  operating  and  regulatory  licenses  add  substantially  to  the  cost  of 
doing business—particularly for SMEs.  
 
23. 
The  major  challenges  include  the  following.  First,  transparency  is  lacking  in  licensing

abuse  by  local  officials.  No  information  window  is  available  to  provide  central  access  to  such 
information.  Second,  without  any  criteria  for  analyzing  whether  the  existing  regulatory  license 
requirements  are  redundant,  no  mechanism  is  available  to  ensure  that  new  license 
requirements  do  not  duplicate  existing  ones,  particularly  as  local  and  central  agencies  are

c. 

Access to Finance 

As of the end of 2003, bank loans to the private sector were 6.9% of GDP—one of the 
24. 
lowest  rates  of  banking  intermediation  in  the  world.  A  study  on  SMEs  by  the  Mekong  Private 
Sector  Development  Facility  (MPDF)  in  November  2000  found  that  over  60%  of  respondents 
considered lack of working capital to be a major problem—70% of the firms needed long-term 
loans. A May 2003 MPDF study on bank financing for SMEs identified almost total absence of 
medium- and long-term lending (less than 2% of SME loans were for more than 2 years).  
 
25. 
Several  factors  have  resulted  in  this  high  risk-lending  environment.  One  is  the  lack  of 
collateral  and  contract  enforcement  by  the  courts.  This  means  that  commercial  banks  must 
assume a considerable risk in lending to SMEs, which are usually less known and established 
than  larger  businesses.  With  ADB  assistance,  the  Government  is  developing  a  legal  and 
institutional  framework  for  secured  transactions  for  movable  properties.  ADB  and  the  World 
Bank  are  also  working  with  the  Government  on  the  Land  Law  and  registration  of  land  as 
immovable  properties.  Furthermore,  as  part  of  the  WTO  accession  requirement,  a  number  of 
development  agencies  are  supporting  the  Government  with  contract  enforcement,  and 
establishing and building the capacity of a commercial court. 
 
26. 
Three  important  barriers  block  SME  access  to  finance.  The  first  is  the  lack  of  a  credit 
information system, which heightens commercial banks' risks in lending. The second relates to 
the  underdeveloped  accounting  and  taxation  systems,  which  deter  SMEs  from  providing 
sufficient  financial  information  to  the  commercial  banks.  Finally,  Cambodia  has  no  nonbank 
financial institutions to provide finance to SMEs.  
 

i. 

Credit Information  

27. 
No  system  currently  exists  to  collect  credit  information  on  borrowers  in  Cambodia.  In 
many developed financial systems, credit information bureaus provide information on potential 
borrowers, this helps reduce risks and transaction costs. Banks use collateral as one method to 
reduce this risk, but the effectiveness of this is constrained by SMEs’ lack of significant assets, 
and  by  difficulties  in  securing  their  assets,  particularly  land/buildings.  Although  NBC  and  the 
Association  of  Banks  in  Cambodia  (ABC)  indicated  a  clear  need  to  establish  such  a  system, 
progress has been limited.  
 

ii. 

Accounting Standards and Taxation System 

28. 
The  high-risk  lending  environment  is  reinforced  by  the  lack  of  financial  statements  for 
most  small  enterprises;  therefore  lenders  have  difficulty  obtaining  an  accurate  picture  of  their 
financial  position.  Although  the  Government  has  made  considerable  progress  with  the  recent 
promulgation  of  the  Accounting  Law  and  the  establishment  of  the  Cambodian  Accounting

Standards  in  2003,  the  accounting  system  is  overly  complicated  for  use  by  SMEs.  Without an 
understanding of accounting procedures, the SMEs are often unable to provide necessary and 
reliable information as required by the commercial banks. With the limitations many SMEs face 
in  providing  collateral  for  loans,  this  becomes  a  significant  barrier.  Furthermore,  many  of  the 
issued accounting standards are not relevant to SMEs and their less complex financial situation. 
Thus,  a  systematic  approach  is  needed  to  disseminate  information  on  the  accounting  system 
and train SMEs in its use (as well as providing SMEs with simplified guidelines and templates), 
focusing  on  their  appropriate  needs.  Another  important  barrier  associated  with  the  lack  of 
financial  information  is  the  complexity  of  the  current,  formal  tax  system,  which  often  provides 
verification  on  the  financial  statements  of  (larger)  SMEs.  Unfamiliarity  with  the  filing  system 
leads to uncertainty, which leads to increased costs for the SMEs (as about $500 is needed to 
hire a tax facilitator/accountant in Cambodia). While considerable efforts are currently ongoing 
with the PFM Working Group (co-chaired by the International Monetary Fund and ADB), these 
efforts need to be complemented by reductions of the barriers faced by SMEs dealing with the 
taxation system.  
 

iii. 

Nonbanking Financial Institutions (Leasing) 

29. 
Currently, the loans from commercial banks (and some lending by licensed microfinance 
institutions) are the only source of formal finance for SMEs, but these funds are generally short-
term  (less  than  1  year).  Internationally,  and  particularly  in  developing  countries,  leasing  has 
become  an  important  source  of  SME  financing,  but  the  lack  of  a  legal  framework  has  been  a 
major  obstacle  to  the  development  of  leasing  in  Cambodia.  For  SMEs,  leasing  offers  an 
alternative form of finance whereby a lessor relies on its ownership of the leased asset and the 
lessee's  cash  flow  to  service  the  lease  payments.  The  benefits  of  leasing  include  simpler 
security arrangements and fewer requirements for historical financial information. However, for 
leasing  to  develop,  the  lessor  must  be  able  to  legally  exercise  ownership  rights  quickly  and 
effectively when any default occurs. With the recent actions to develop the secured transactions 
and  commercial  court  system,  the  timing  would  be  appropriate  for  formulating  the  legal 
framework to create an enabling environment for leasing industry development.

Program’s emphasis on the need to reduce the costs of doing business can be achieved with

inter-ministerial coordination body will be established to lay the foundation for the Government's

Developing  an  enabling  business  environment  is  particularly  relevant  for  Cambodia, 
where significant institutional and legislative components are missing or poorly developed, and 
SMEs  operate  mostly  in  the  informal  sector.  The  components,  both  legal  and  institutional, 
essential for an efficient economy need to be established. Through the analysis of the program 
preparatory TA, and based on dialogue with the Government and other stakeholders, the issues 
selected  for  support  under  the  Program  were  determined  by  (i)  their  contribution  to  improving 
the  business  environment;  (ii)  the  perceived  commitment  of  the  Government  to  required 
reforms;  (iii)  ADB's  past  and  ongoing  operations  in  Cambodia;  and  (iv)  the  Program’s

a. 

Improve the Business Registration Process 

50. 
The  main  objective  is  to  reduce  the  barriers  and  enhance  the  transparency  associated 
with business registration.  The proposed reform aims to induce a more developed commercial 
system  by  allowing  enterprises  to  enter  the  formal  sector  and,  in  the  case  of  incorporation, 
establish legal entities as companies and protect the rights of the shareholders.  
 
51.  MOC  will  undertake  several  components  for  registration  reform.  First,  the  Program 
includes  activities  to  reduce  registration  procedures  and  documentation  requirements  of  both 
central and local governments. This is intended to make the Cambodian system consistent with 
international  experience.  As  specified  in  the  policy  matrix,  about  half  of  the  registration 
requirements are to be removed as a result of the proposed reform. Second, the Program aims 
to  reduce  the  costs  associated  with  registration.  Based  on  the  reduction  of  the  current  costs 
(mostly  by  removing  unnecessary  requirements),  barriers  against  business  registration  will  be 
significantly reduced. Third, the Program includes  the development of  a pilot program that  will 
permit  provincial  registration.  Procedures  to  effectively  implement  this  decentralization  plan, 
which will be compatible with the provisions of the (draft) Law on Commercial Enterprises, will 
be  developed.  Fourth,  the  Government  is  to  decrease  the  minimum  capital  requirement  for 
newly  registering  enterprises.  The  current  $5,000  requirement  will  be  reduced  to  $1,000  by 
amending  the  (draft)  Commercial  Enterprise  Law,  which  is  soon  to  be  promulgated  by  the 
National Assembly.23 Fifth, the Program includes the introduction of an information technology-
based registration system. Enhanced transparency will result when the various procedures and 
requirements  are  clarified  through  the  issuance  of  new  legal  documents.  An  effective 
information technology-based system should lead to eventual decentralization of the system.

52. 
The main objective in business licensing reform is to reduce the costs of doing business 
in  Cambodia,  specifically  the  regulatory  compliance  costs.  Although  the  Government  must 
maintain  an  effective  licensing/inspection  system,  it  should  not  be  overly  burdensome  for 
enterprises. Thus, the Program seeks to streamline current licensing (by eliminating duplicative 
licenses  and/or  their  requirements)  and  ensure  that  new  licenses  to  be  required  will  not  be 
redundant.  Furthermore,  enterprises  should  be  given  the  right  to  ask  for  clarification  on  the

ministries  affecting  SMEs.24 Then,  it  will  develop  criteria  on  current  licenses  to  streamline  the 
licensing  process  and  requirements  deemed  to  be  unnecessary  or  overly  burdensome.  The 
subcommittee will also develop a set of criteria for any new operating and regulatory licenses.

issue licenses.

Enhance SME Access to Finance 

55. 
The  Program's  components  on  finance  are  closely  linked  with  the  ongoing  FSPL.  The 
FSPL aims to promote the development of a sound, market-based financial system to support 
enhanced resource mobilization and sustainable economic growth by establishing a foundation 
for  banking,  as  well  as  financial  market  development.  The  challenge  associated  with  SMEs' 
access to finance cannot be solely resolved by financial sector development, as one of the key 
barriers relates to developing a viable group of SMEs as potential borrowers. In fact, the recent

Accordingly, the Program emphasizes institutional development of needed infrastructure 
to  reduce  the  risks  and costs  of  lending  to  SMEs,  including  (i)  developing  a  credit  information

simplified accounting guidelines that are more relevant to the needs of smaller enterprises, but 
meet  the  requirements  of  potential  lenders  for  information  on  enterprises;  (iii)  formulating 
simplified  guidelines  and  standard  forms  for  the  tax  filing  system;  and  (iv)  developing  a 
framework  for  leasing  as  a  potential  source  of  longer  term  financing.  The  work  on  leasing  is 
supported by the FSPL's efforts to establish a secured transactions system.  
 

a. 

Develop a Credit Information System 

The main objective is to reduce the risks of commercial banks in their lending activities. 
57. 
A  long-term  goal  associated  with  this  is  to  develop  non-collateral-based  lending.  Cambodia 
does  not  have  a  public/private  credit  information  registry,  and  as  a  consequence,  transaction 
costs for lenders remain high. 
  
58. 
The  components  for  this  activity  include  the  following:  First,  NBC,  with  ABC,  is  to 
develop  a  credit  information  system  on  a  pilot  basis,  with  the  eventual  goal  of  establishing  a 
private  credit  bureau  when  the  market  is  more  developed.  Participation  by  banks  will  be 
voluntary. A database will be established to receive and provide credit information. Information 
will  be  collected  from  participating  banks,  and  disclosed  to  the  same  banks,  i.e.,  a  reciprocal 
system.  The  system's  database  protects  the  identity  of  existing  lenders  by  not  disclosing  the 
name of the bank providing the information (i.e., name of lender). The database is to be updated 
monthly  from  information  provided  by  participants.  Participants  have  access  to  the  database. 
Suitable security arrangements must be developed to maintain the integrity of the system and to 
ensure that participating banks do not relay incorrect information.

81. 
The Program’s impact on SMEs will be the creation of a more predictable and efficient 
business environment. This will occur through (i) coordination and a more strategic direction in 
government  SME  development;  (ii)  reduction  of  and  greater  transparency  in,  regulatory 
requirements; and (iii) improved access to finance.

SMEs.  It  will  also  result  in  government  programs  taking  onboard  the  lessons  learned  in  SME 
development, and applying best practice to programs and government interventions in the SME 
sector.  The  Program  will  also  reduce  the  cost  of  doing  business  in  time  and  money.  By 
simplifying  and  computerizing  the  business  registration  process,  it  will  encourage  more 
enterprises to enter the formal sector. Benefits to entering the formal sector include access to 
government services; recourse to, and protection under the legal system; and enhanced access 
to  finance.  Finally,  the  Program  will  enhance  access  to  finance,  by  increasing  the  range  of 
financial  products  such  as  leasing,  and  improving  information  systems  such  as  a  credit 
information  sharing  mechanism.  Financial  institutions  will  be  able  to  make  more  informed 
decisions; thus leading to reduced cost of financing.

Successful implementation of the Program entails three risks. The first relates to a low

TA  is  being  provided  to  support  Program  implementation,  and  provide  capacity-building

A second risk relates to lack of coordination among various Government agencies. The 
Program  requires  close  coordination  among  the  relevant  authorities—both  horizontally  among 
different  ministries  and  agencies  concerned,  and  vertically  with  the  provincial  and  district 
authorities. Consultation and coordination will be required with other stakeholders active in SME 
development.  The  Program  design  has  taken  this  risk  into  consideration  and  emphasizes 
interagency  coordination  mechanisms,  particularly  by  establishing  an 
inter-ministerial 
coordination body (National SME Subcommittee) with private sector participation. 
 
86. 
A third risk relates to good governance of the central and local government authorities. 
Local governance is particularly important, as the Program's most direct impact on SMEs will be 
at  the  local  level.  These  risks,  common  to  several  programs,  are  being  addressed  by  the 
Government's PFM, supported by a number of development agencies, including ADB.

expected  to  contribute  to  promoting  transparency,  accountability,  and  effectiveness  among

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Cambodia: 
 
All  measures  adopted  under  the  Small  and  Medium  Enterprise  Development  Program  (the  Program)  support  the 
Government in undertaking market-friendly interventions and creating the bases for an enabling environment for small 
and medium enterprises (SMEs) and private sector development (PSD). In Cambodia, SMEs dominate the economy 
and  are  a  major  source  of  employment  for  the  poor.  The  Program  is  expected  to  increase  SMEs’  contribution  to 
economic  growth,  employment  generation,  and  poverty  reduction.  Through  creating  a  more  conducive  business 
environment  by  coordinating  the  Government’s  SME  strategies,  minimizing  regulatory  requirements,  and  enhancing 
access to finance, Program in the medium- to long-term will have significant impact on SMEs, increase opportunities 
for employment, and reduce the incidence of poverty in urban areas. To the extent possible, the Program will ensure 
that the process of SME policy drafting, validation, and implementation follow the Government’s stated goal to foster 
participation,  and  promote  social  inclusion  and  gender-responsiveness  in  pursuing  its  poverty  reduction  efforts.  A 
significant  proportion  of  SMEs  are  found  in  the  rural  area.  Extending  the  outreach  and  impact  of  the  proposed 
interventions  beyond  the  densely  populated  cities  of  Phnom  Penh,  Sianoukville,  Siem  Reap,  and  Battambang  is  a 
critical risk. 
 
 
B. 
 
In  the  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (2003–2005),  a  number  of  investment  studies  identified  the  following 
issues as barriers to private sector development and micro- and SME development: poor physical infrastructure, high 
costs  of  transportation,  electricity  and  telecommunications,  safety  and  respect  of  signed  contracts,  limited  human 
resources,  increasing  labor  costs,  high  transactions  costs,  and  the  lack  of  proper  legal  and  judicial  systems. 
Cambodia’s Poverty Partnership Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) further reiterates the critical areas 
of ADB support, which include developing the financial sector, following the Financial Sector Blueprint, and supporting 
reforms  of  the  legal  infrastructure  for  business.  In  line  with  the  priorities  set  forth  in  the  National  Poverty  Reduction 
Strategy  and  Poverty  Partnership  Agreement,  the  Program  aims  to  address  some  of  the  structural  policy  and 
legal/regulatory impediments to PSD and micro- and SME development. Identified priorities include the following: 
 

Poverty Analysis 

•  Coordination and a more strategic direction in SME development. Greater coordination and strategic direction in 
SME policy is expected to result in better coordination between ministries and a more consistent market-friendly 
approach in dealing with SMEs. It will also result in Government programs taking on board the lessons learned 
in SME development and applying best practice to program and Government interventions in the SME sector. 

 
•  Reduction and greater transparency in the regulatory requirements. The Program will reduce the costs of doing 
business. By simplifying and computerizing the business registration process, it will encourage more enterprises 
to  enter  the  formal  sector,  thus  benefiting  from  access  to  Government  services,  recourse  to  and  protection 
under the legal system, and enhanced access to finance. In the agro-industry sector, where informality and poor 
infrastructures  are  critical,  the  Program  is  expected  to  have  significant  benefits,  by  improving  entry  into  the 
formal  sector  through  registration  reform,  licensing  review  process,  and  improved  inspections  system.  The 
portal  site  will  assist  in  availability  of  information  and  improve  value  chains,  an  essential  component  for  a 
competitive market. 

Improved  access  to  finance.  Finally,  the  Program  will  enhance  access  to  finance,  through  a  greater  range  of 
financial products such as leasing, and through better information systems such as a credit information sharing 
mechanisms allowing financial institutions to make more informed decisions. Better information systems reduce 
risks  and  assuming  all  else  is  equal,  will  reduce  the  cost  of  finance.  The  successful  implementation  of  the 
Program will incrementally improve the environment for doing business, leading to greater economic activity and 
more employment, which will have a catalytic impact of PSD in Cambodia.

women  entrepreneurs  and  their  contribution  to  the  policy-drafting  and  decision-making  processes,  the  SME 
development framework will be drafted based on an iterative and gender-inclusive consultative process. This process 
will imply a systematic consultation with key line ministries, private sector representatives, relying upon the Ministry of 
Women’s Affairs’ extensive outreach and network with business associations and women’s entrepreneurs. 
 
Data  and  information  on  SMEs  are  scarce  and  unreliable  in  Cambodia,  and  present  formidable  challenges  in 
benchmarking  the  social  impact  of  the  proposed  interventions.  To  gather  more  accurate  information  on  the  SME 
sector and to better reflect women’s and women’s entrepreneurs’ contribution to private sector and SME development,

interventions. In this respect, the finalization of ADB-funded micro- and small-enterprises development framework for 
the  Ministry  of  Women’s  Affairs’  Strategic  Plan  [TA-3947-CAM]  will  contribute  to  defining  specific  needs  and
